statement:
The exterior angle of an angle of triangle is greater than both other
angles of the triangle.

[*Proof.*]{} Let us study in an arbitrary triangle $ABC$ for example the
exterior angle $\wedge ACD$ where $D$ is point on the lengthening of the
side $BC$ nearer to $C$ than to $B$. Let $E$ be the midpoint of $AC$.
Let $BE$ be the median of the triangle. We find on its lengthening the
point $F$ such that $EF = EB$. Then the triangles $ABE$ and $CEF$ are
congruent (SAS). Consequently, we have $\wedge ECF \;=\;\, \wedge BAE$
and therefore $\wedge ACD \;>\; \wedge BAC$. Analogically one shows that
$\wedge ACD \;>\; \wedge ABC$. $\Box$

[8]{} : [*Lobatsevski geomeetria*]{}. Kirjastus “Valgus”, Tallinn
(1992).
